questions.text: The Tensor Tympani muscle is supplied by which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
The middle ear consists of Two muscles they are Tensor tympani and stapedius.

  • Tensor tympani muscle attaches to the upper part of handle of malleus and tenses the tympanic membrane, Tensor tympani develops from first arch thus it is supplied by a Branch of mandibular nerve which is a branch of trigeminal nerve. Thus option A is correct answer.
  • Stapedius muscle attaches to the neck of the stapes and help to dampen very loud sound thus preventing the noise trauma to the inner ear. It is a muscle of second arch thus it is supplied by facial nerve. Hence option b, c and d are not correct.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: tensor tympani is supplied by mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve

Tag: Ear anatomy

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th Edition, Page Number:10.

choices.text: This test is based on to induce nystagmus by thermal stimulation of the vestibular system
It is based on vestibulo ocular reflex
This test is based on to induce nystagmus by producing pressure changes in the external canal which are transmitted to labyrinth.
It is based on vestibulo cerebellar reflex.

questions.text: What is the principle behind the Halmagyi test?
questions.solution:
The Halmagyi test is also known as Head thrust test. It is based on vestibulo ocular reflex. Patient sits or stands and gazes at examiner s nose. Then his head, which is head between examiner s hands, is suddenly moved on right or left side.


A normal person will be able to fix his eyes on the primary position but one with hypoactive labyrinth will show a saccade to the healthy side to correct head position. Thus option B is correct.

Option A represents caloric test

Option C represents fistula test

Option D represents Test for cerebellar dysfunction.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Halmagyi test based on vestibule ocular reflex

Tag: Ear, assessment of vestibular function.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PLdhingra 8thEdition, page number:49.

choices.text: Delayed MRI after intratympanic or intra venous injection of gadolinium

questions.text: Which of the following is the most promising technique in diagnosing Menieres disease?
questions.solution:
Investigations in Meniere's disease includes:

  • Pure tone audiometry : Sensorineural hearing loss at lower frequencies.
  • Speech audiometry: score is usually between 55 to 85 % between attacks but it is severely impaired during the attack.
  • Special audiometry test: a) Recruitment test is positive, b) SISI test score is better than 70%. C) tone decay test less than 20 db.
  • Electrocochleography: SP/AP ratio is greater than 30% in Meniere's disease. Diagnostic of the disease. But not as specific as gadolinium MRI. Thus option D is not true
  • Caloric test : shows reduced response But not very sensitive thus option D is not true .
  • Glycerol test : glycerol is a dehydrating agent. It reduces endolymphatic pressure and improves hearing.
  • Gadolinium contrast MRI : it is one of the most promising tool for diagnosing Meniere's disease. The gadolinium contrast binds with the endolymph . Thus it's leakage in Meniere's disease cam be traced.

Tag: Ear, Meniere's disease

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th Edition, Page Number:121.

questions.text: Tumarkin crisis where patient develops sudden loss of consciousness is caused by?
questions.solution:
The following are the variants of Meniere's disease:

  • Cochlear hydrops : Here only the cochlear signs and symptoms are present. Vertigo is absent.
  • Vestibular hydrops: The patient gets typical attacks of episodic vertigo while cochlear function remains normal. It is only with time that typical picture of meniere disease develop.
  • Drop attacks ( Tumarkins Otolithic crisis) : In this a sudden drop attack develops without loss of consciousness. There is no vertigo or fluctuations in hearing loss. Possible mechanism is the deformation of the otolithic membrane of the utricle or saccule due to changes in endolymphatic pressure. Thus option c is correct.
  • lermoyez syndrome : Here the symptoms of Meniere's disease are seen in reverse First there is hearing loss followed by vertigo.

In vestibular neuronitis There is inflammation of vestibular nerve due to possible viral etiology. Tumarkin crisis is not a feature thus option A is not true.

In acoustic neuroma vertigo develops due to compression of vestibular nerve. Tumarkin crisis is also not it's feature. Thus option B is not true.

In Superior semi-circular canal dehiscence there is a third window developed which leads to leakage of perilymph. Thus option D is not true.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Drop attacks ( Tumarkins Otolithic crisis) : In this a sudden drop attack develops without loss of consciousness seen in Meniere's disease due to otolith dysfunction

Tag: Ear, vestibular disorders

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th Edition, Page Number:122.

Tag: Ear, Anatomy.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8thEdition, Page Number:14-15.

choices.text: Disproportionate hearing loss with early facial palsy
CT temporal bone is the radiological investigation of choice
Histopathological examination of a biopsy specimen confirms diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding Tuberculous otitis media?
questions.solution:
Tuberculous otitis media in most of the cases the infection occurs secondary to pulmonary TB. The infection reaches the middle ear through eustachian tube.

Clinical features:

1) painless ear discharge : Ear ache is characteristically absent. Discharge is often foul smelling.

2) perforation: Multiple perforations, two or three in number are seen in pars tensa.

3) Hearing loss: There is severe hearing loss which is out of proportion to symptoms. It is mostly conductive. Thus option b is not true here.

4) facial paralysis: it is a common complication and develops relatively early.


Investigations: Culture of ear discharge for tubercle bacilli.

CT scam temporal bone with contrast shows extent of the disease.

Histopathology of Biopsy specimen shows granuloma and caseous necrosis. Thus option C And D are not true here.

Option A is not a feature of TB otitis media thus option A is correct answer.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: tuberculous otitis media, is a painless otitis media with multiple perforation of tympanic membrane

Tag: Ear, CSOM

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th Edition, Page Number:88.

questions.text: All of the following management are accepted for Far- advanced otosclerosis except?
questions.solution:
• Otosclerosis also known as otospongiosis is a Primary disease of bony labyrinth. In this one or more foci of irregularly laid spongy bone replace part of normally dense enchondral layer of bony otic capsule.
  • Treatment: Medical : There is no medical treatment that cures otosclerosis. Sodium fluoride is tried to hasten the maturity of active focus and arrest further cochlear loss.
  • Surgical : Stapedectomy and stapedotomy: Here the fixed otosclerotic stapes is removed and prosthesis is inserted between the incus and the oval window.
  • Cochlear implant : It can be used in advanced cases in which sensorineural hearing loss has also developed and patient is not benefitted by hearing aid.
  • Hearing aid : Patient who refuse surgery or are unfit for surgery can use hearing aid. It is an effective alternative. Thus option A C and D are not correct answers.

Since BAHA is not used in otosclerosis option B is correct answer here.

Tag: Ear, Otosclerosis.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th Edition, Page Number:105.

questions.text: Most common type of primary temporal bone cancer in adults is.
questions.solution:
Tumors of middle ear and mastoid can be divided into following:

Primary tumors:

  1. Benign : paraganglioma, schwanomma of facial nerve, haemangioma, carcinoid, adenoma.
  2. Malignant: squamous cell carcinoma, sarcoma.

Secondary tumors : arises from adjacent areas external auditory canal, parotid gland and nasopharynx.

Metastasis from carcinoma breast, Thyroid and prostate.

Squamous cell carcinoma of temporal bone and mastoid is a rare disease being one case in 20 000 new patients examined. But is is the commonest primary mastoid tumor. Adenocarcinoma may be seen occasionally. It arises from the glandular elements.

A combination of radiotherapy and Surgery gives best results. Surgery consists of radical mastoidectomy, subtotal petrosectomy depending upon the extent of the tumor

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The most common type of primary temporal bone cancer in adult is squamous cell carcinoma.

Tag: Ear, Benign and malignant tumors.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th Edition, Page Number:130- 131.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th Edition, Page Number:433-434.

questions.text: During the tympanoplasty it was found that malleus is present but stapes suprastructure is absent Then it is classified as?
questions.solution:
Austin classified the ossicular erosion into four types based on presence or absence of malleus handle and stapes suprastructure. Assuming the incus to be absent in all of the cases.

Type A : M+S+: Both malleus handle and stapes suprastructure is present. It is reconstructed using Partial ossicular replacement prosthesis.

Type B: M+S- : Here malleus handle is present but stapes suprastructure is absent. It has to be reconstructed by Total ossicular replacement prosthesis.

Type C M- S+: Here malleus handle and incus is absent only stapes is present. It is reconstructed using PORP.

Type D M-S-: Here both malleus handle and stapes suprastructure is absent. It has to be reconstructed by TORP.

Tag: Ear, CSOM


Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th Edition, Page Number:84.

questions.text: Fluctuating deafness in a case of temporal bone trauma is because of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Fistula of labyrinth or circumscribed labyrinthitis. There is thinning or erosion of bony capsule of labyrinth, usually of horizontal semicircular canal.

Causes: Surgery, accidental trauma , CSOM with cholesteatoma and neoplasm.

Clinical features: A part of membranous labyrinth is exposed and sensitive to pressure changes. Patient complains of Transient vertigo and fluctuating hearing loss.

Fistula test is positive. Siegel speculum can also elicit vertigo.

Treatment includes surgical exploration and locating the site of leak and covering it using fascia. Antibiotics and antiemetics.

Tag 1 : Ear, CSOM , Trauma

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edition, page number:96.

questions.text: Which of the following condition is associated with cochlear recruitment ?
questions.solution:
It is a phenomenon of abnormal growth in loudness. The ear which does not hear low intensity sounds as loud as or even louder than a normal ear.

Thus a loud sound which is tolerable to a normal person may grow to abnormal levels of loudness in recruiting ear and thus becomes intolerable. Patients with recruitment are poor candidates for hearing aids.

Recruitement is typically seen in conditions involving cochlea such as Meniere's disease and presbyacusis. And thus it helps in differentiating cochlear from retrocochlear pathology.

Tag 1 : Ear, Meniere's disease

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edition, page number:30.

questions.text: BPPV is most commonly caused by canaliths in ?
questions.solution:
Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo BPPV is characterized by vertigo when the head is placed in the certain critical position such as picking an object from overhead shelf.

There is no hearing loss or other neurological symptoms.

It has been demonstrated that otoconial debris, consisting of crystals of calcium carbonate, is released from degenerating macula of the utricle and floats freely in the endolymph.

When it settles in the cupula of the posterior semicircular canal in critical head position it causes vertigo. Vertigo is fatiguable on assuming the same position repeatedly due to dispersal of otoconia but can be induced again after a period of rest.

Tag 1 : Ear, vestibular disorders

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edition, page number:52.

questions.text: Causes of discharging mastoid cavity includes?
questions.solution:
Steps of mastoidectomy includes:

  1. Incision: A curved post aural incision about 1 cm behind but parallel to the retroauricular sulcus starting at highest attachment of pinna to the mastoid tip.
  2. Exposure of lateral surface of mastoid and mac Ewan triangle
  3. Removal of the bone and exposure of attic and antrum : with the help of a light burr, bone is removed from suprameatal triangle, spine of henle.
  4. Removal of bridge and buttress: Deeper part of superior osseous mental wall that bridges over notch of ricinus is removed.
  5. Lowering the ridge: The deeper part of posterior mental wall that overlies the vertical part of facial nerve is called facial ridge. It is removed as much as possible within the safety of 7th Inappropriate lowering of this ridge can lead to persistent discharge from cavity postoperatively.
  6. Toilet of middle ear inspection of cavity and irrigation.
  7. Removal of mastoid tip: lateral wall of the mastoid tip is removed, exposing muscle fibers of digastric. Inappropriate Removal leads to persistent ear discharge postoperatively.
  8. Meatoplasty : A flap based laterally at the cochlea is raised from posterior and superior mental wall and turned into mastoid cavity into external auditory canal. Inappropriate meatoplasty can lead to persistent ear discharge postoperatively.
  9. Closure.

Thus all the options are correct.

Tag 1 : Ear, CSOM

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edition, page number:477.

questions.text: Which of the following is the subjective test of hearing?
questions.solution:
The test which is depended on patients active response for forming a report are called subjective tests. In audiology test such as Tunning fork tests, pure tone audiometry, speech audiometry are Subjective tests.

The test which is not depended on patient s response for forming a report which means that the required measurements can be done by the technique used in the test and it does not require a active response from patient are called objective test.

They include Otoacoustic emissions, impedence audiometry, Brain stem evoked response audiometry, ASSR. These test are specifically used in neonatal hearing assessment, assessment of comatose patients and in malingering.

Tag 1 : Ear, Audiometry

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edition, page number:25.
